skill.name: writing-skills
skill.description: Use when creating new skills, editing existing skills, or verifying skills work before deployment - applies TDD to process documentation by testing with subagents before writing, iterating until bulletproof against rationalization

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation and best practices for writing AI skills. No executable code, network calls, or file system access beyond its own directory. All content is educational and poses no security risks.

content.user_title: Create bulletproof AI skills with TDD methodology
content.value_statement: Writing effective AI skills is hard. This skill applies test-driven development principles to skill documentation, ensuring your skills actually work under pressure before deployment.
actual_capabilities: Applies TDD RED-GREEN-REFACTOR cycle to skill documentation
Tests skills with pressure scenarios using subagents before writing
Identifies and closes rationalization loopholes in skill design
Provides persuasion principles based on psychology research
Includes comprehensive checklists for skill deployment
limitations: Requires understanding of test-driven development fundamentals
Skills must be tested with real scenarios before deployment
Process can be time-intensive for complex skills
Limited to documentation and process guidance only

use_cases.title: Build robust AI skills that work under pressure
use_cases.description: Apply TDD principles to ensure your skills handle edge cases and resist rationalization when agents are under time pressure or stress.

use_cases.title: Create consistent, tested skill documentation
use_cases.description: Establish team standards for skill creation with proven testing methodologies that ensure quality and reliability.

use_cases.title: Publish bulletproof skills to marketplaces
use_cases.description: Use rigorous testing to create skills that work reliably across different AI models and usage scenarios.

prompt_templates.title: Test existing skill
prompt_templates.scenario: Verify a skill works under pressure
prompt_templates.prompt: I have a skill about [TOPIC]. Test it with subagents using pressure scenarios to see if it resists rationalization. Document any failures.

prompt_templates.title: Create new skill
prompt_templates.scenario: Build a skill using TDD approach
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to create a skill for [PROBLEM]. Use the TDD approach: first test with subagents to see baseline behavior, then write minimal skill, then iterate to close loopholes.

prompt_templates.title: Improve skill compliance
prompt_templates.scenario: Make a skill more resistant to violations
prompt_templates.prompt: My skill about [TOPIC] has compliance issues. Help me apply persuasion principles and add explicit anti-rationalization counters to make it bulletproof.

prompt_templates.title: Skill deployment checklist
prompt_templates.scenario: Ensure skill is ready for production
prompt_templates.prompt: I'm ready to deploy my skill about [TOPIC]. Walk me through the complete deployment checklist to ensure it's properly tested and documented.

output_examples.input: Test my skill about defensive programming
output: Baseline test results: Agent skipped input validation when under time pressure
Rationalizations used: 'This is just a demo', 'Input looks safe'
Skill gaps identified: No explicit requirement for validation before processing
Recommended fixes: Add 'YOU MUST validate all inputs' with specific examples
Pressure scenario passed after skill update: Agent now validates despite time pressure

best_practices: Always test skills with subagents before deployment - watch them fail first
Use imperative language and explicit anti-rationalization counters for discipline skills
Keep skills concise and focused - one excellent example beats many mediocre ones
Include searchable keywords in descriptions for better discovery
anti_patterns: Writing skills without testing - untested skills always have issues
Using narrative examples - too specific and not reusable
Creating multi-language examples - dilutes quality and adds maintenance burden
Skipping the RED phase - you must see baseline behavior before writing the skill

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with all Claude models?
faq.answer: Yes, the TDD principles apply universally across Claude Haiku, Sonnet, and Opus models.

faq.question: How long does the TDD process take for skill creation?
faq.answer: Typically 15-30 minutes for simple skills, longer for complex ones. Testing saves hours of debugging later.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with existing skill development workflows?
faq.answer: Yes, this methodology complements any skill development process by adding rigorous testing before deployment.

faq.question: Is my data safe when testing skills?
faq.answer: Yes, this skill only provides documentation and testing methodologies. No data is collected or transmitted.

faq.question: What if my skill fails testing repeatedly?
faq.answer: This indicates fundamental issues with the skill design. Simplify the skill or break it into smaller, testable components.

faq.question: How does this compare to traditional software testing?
faq.answer: It's the same RED-GREEN-REFACTOR cycle applied to AI skill documentation instead of code.
